text:
it basically finds the diameters of the gears from dp (diametral pitch) and number of teeth.
This is easy because the number of teeth divided by dp is the diameter. then it finds the radius of each gear, adds them together, and adds .002"

text:
Parts of a ball shifter:
Plunger: connected to the piston, pushes the ball bearing out
Cylinder: the gearbox shaft. Rotationally connected to things on it by the ball bearings
Gears (or whatever is on the shifter part of the cylinder): have special notches that hold ball bearings. Can be locked and unlocked from rotating with the shaft
Piston (pneumatic)
Piston to plunger connection: basically a bearing and hardware to connect it

Its easiest to use cots options for all of these parts, but that will impose some limitations.



Thinking about where the shifter goes:
The shifter can either lock/unlock the gear to the cylinder or the drum to the cylinder
Cots gears already have notches, where a drum wouldnt.
The shifter has to disconnect (and reconnect) the motors from the drum
The gearbox is single stage, so there is only one shaft (except for the motor shafts)
The drum has to spin both directions (powered rope in, free rope out)
The climber must be ratcheted when in gear, but not ratcheted when out of gear
The drum cant be ratcheted
So the shaft has to be ratcheted and the drum has to disconnect from the shifter.

elements.text:
Parts of a ball shifter:
Plunger: connected to the piston, pushes the ball bearing out
Cylinder: the gearbox shaft. Rotationally connected to things on it by the ball bearings
Gears (or whatever is on the shifter part of the cylinder): have special notches that hold ball bearings. Can be locked and unlocked from rotating with the shaft
Piston (pneumatic)
Piston to plunger connection: basically a bearing and hardware to connect it

Its easiest to use cots options for all of these parts, but that will impose some limitations.



Thinking about where the shifter goes:
The shifter can either lock/unlock the gear to the cylinder or the drum to the cylinder
Cots gears already have notches, where a drum wouldnt.
The shifter has to disconnect (and reconnect) the motors from the drum
The gearbox is single stage, so there is only one shaft (except for the motor shafts)
The drum has to spin both directions (powered rope in, free rope out)
The climber must be ratcheted when in gear, but not ratcheted when out of gear
The drum cant be ratcheted
So the shaft has to be ratcheted and the drum has to disconnect from the shifter.
